title: 111_hr5675
content: The "National Border and Homeland Security Act of 2010" prioritizes distributing funds under the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program to states on the northern or southern border and political subdivisions with large populations of unlawfully present aliens. Additionally, the Act addresses fencing and operational control of the Southwest border. SEC. 3 amends deadlines for fencing and operational control of the Southwest border to December 31, 2012. SEC. 4 focuses on Border Patrol agents. SEC. 4 mandates an increase in the number of full-time Border Patrol agents for fiscal years 2011 to 2014, with deployments to both the southern and northern borders. SEC. 5 mandates an increase of at least 200 United States Customs and Border Protection officers at ports of entry for fiscal years 2011 to 2014. SEC. 6 requires complete implementation of the US-VISIT automated entry and exit control system by December 31, 2011. SEC. 7 prohibits impeding certain activities of the Secretary of Homeland Security related to border security. On public lands in the United States, the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture cannot hinder the Secretary of Homeland Security's efforts to achieve operational control. This includes activities outlined in the Secure Fence Act of 2006. The text chunk discusses the authorization for expanding capacity to double the number of Operation Streamline prosecutions in Federal district courts. This includes the appointment of additional deputies, clerical assistants, and employees without requiring approval by the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. The United States Code allows for the appointment of additional magistrate judges and law clerks in district courts for Operation Streamline prosecutions of aliens for offenses under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The United States district court can be in the District of Arizona, New Mexico, Southern California, Southern Texas, or Western Texas. SEC. 9. INCREASED PENALTY FOR ENTRY OF ALIEN AT IMPROPER TIME OR PLACE OR MISREPRESENTATION AND CONCEALMENT OF FACTS. Section 275 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase penalties for certain offenses related to entry of aliens. The minimum mandatory terms of imprisonment are adjusted for first and subsequent offenses. The amendment to Section 275 of the Immigration and Nationality Act increases penalties for certain offenses related to entry of aliens, with adjusted minimum mandatory terms of imprisonment for first and subsequent offenses. Exemptions from the penalties include children under 18, parents traveling with children under 18, and aliens with life-threatening health conditions. SEC. 10. GLOBAL NUCLEAR DETECTION ARCHITECTURE. Section 1902(a) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include developing objectives, identifying roles and responsibilities, ensuring funding availability, and employing monitoring mechanisms to achieve objectives. In amending Section 1902(a) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002, mechanisms are established to determine progress towards objectives, roles and responsibilities are identified, funding availability is ensured, and monitoring mechanisms are employed to achieve objectives. Additionally, paragraph (14) is revised to refer to "this subsection" instead of specific paragraphs. SEC. 11. The Secretary of Homeland Security must determine and procure next-generation portable radiation detectors and radioactive isotope identification devices for Border Patrol agents by July 1, 2011. SEC. 12. Port Security Grants. SEC. 12. Port Security Grants. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2007 through 2014 to carry out port security measures. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to develop a strategic plan to detect and interdict biological and chemical weapons entering the United States by July 1, 2011. Implementation of the plan must be completed by July 1, 2014. Reports on the plan's progress must be submitted to Congress annually starting from July 1, 2012.
